awd_titl_txt: DDRIG in DRMS: Communicating risks in a sensational media environment-Using short video multimodal features to attract attention and reduce psychological reactance for persuasion
awd_abstract_narration:
In today’s social media landscape, dominated by short videos, competition for public attention affects information integrity in science communication. Organizations and individuals use various multimodal features such as images, background music, and visual effects to maximize message viewing in hopes of shifting public opinion toward important issues. Message sensation value (MSV) captures how content and format features of messages can influence audience engagement, directly or indirectly changing public opinion towards the issues. Previous studies present conflicting views on MSV’s impacts on persuasion. This research captures and tests MSV’s impacts using a novel short video dataset, aiming to enable science and health communicators, policymakers, and technological platforms to better understand and address the effects of sensational social media features in influencing how people consume and are influenced by these messages. 

This research employs a combination of large-scale computational video analysis and an online experiment. First, the project uses computational techniques to systematically identify multi-modal features in 10,000 videos of varying message content quality and examines the associations of 18 multi-modal features to video engagement metrics. This research provides evidence on the role played by multi-modal features in the propagation of messages. Second, this research conducts an online experiment (N = 1,500) with a 2 (MSV: high, low) by 2 (belief congruence: pro-attitudinal, counter-attitudinal) by 2 (issues) between-subject design, plus a control condition. The experiment tests competing theoretical mechanisms of MSV’s persuasive effects on attention, credibility judgment, psychological reactance, and risk perceptions for individuals with varying pre-existing attitudes on the two critical issues. This research provides a theory-informed investigation of sensational media features used in science and risk communication. The findings shed light on effective strategies for communicating health and climate risks and scientific information and maintaining information integrity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Given the widespread popularity of short video platforms, this dissertation project investigates the attentional and psychological mechanisms through which multimodal features exert persuasive effects on improving risk perceptions regarding important scientific issues such as vaccines and climate change. The project is grounded in the theoretical framework of message sensation value (MSV), a construct that quantifies how audiovisual content features attract attention and influence information processing and subsequent persuasive outcomes. This project employs a combination of two complementary methodological approaches. The first uses computational video analysis to identify multimodal features in science short videos that contribute to increased public engagement on social media platforms. The second approach involves online experiments to test the causal mechanisms by which sensational multimodal features influence audience attention, credibility judgments, psychological reactance, and risk perceptions.

The first study is an observational analysis that uses multimodal analysis and machine learning methods to systematically examine how features such as visual brightness, audio tempo, and facial expressions collectively influence audience attention and engagement with short videos. We extracted multimodal features from 1,200 short science videos using computational tools and applied machine learning to model the relationship between these features and human ratings of message sensation value (MSV), or how sensational each video felt. This resulted in a new computational measure that automatically quantifies a video’s MSV based on its audiovisual characteristics. We found that MSV reliably predicted engagement outcomes, including views, likes, and shares. Notably, an analysis of over 10,000 short videos across three platforms revealed an inverted U-shaped relationship: engagement peaked at a moderate level of MSV, suggesting that while sensation can attract attention, too much may dampen its effectiveness.

The second study investigates the attentional and persuasive effects of message sensation value (MSV). We conducted a 3 (MSV: low, medium, high) × 2 (issue: COVID-19, climate change) within-subject online experiment. Participants with varying pre-existing attitudes toward these issues were exposed to short video stimuli and responded to questions assessing message processing and evaluation. Building on findings from Study 1, we created experimental video stimuli that reflected three different levels of MSV. This experiment involved 1,700 participants and produced two key findings. First, MSV had an overall positive effect on message processing and persuasiveness: both high- and medium-MSV videos enhanced cognitive and affective processing, increased perceived message credibility, and boosted intentions to engage with the videos, compared to low-MSV videos. Second, age moderated the effects of MSV, with positive impacts more pronounced among young adults, while older adults showed no significant response to MSV levels on persuasive outcomes. Lastly, MSV’s effects were consistent regardless of belief congruence, suggesting that its persuasive benefits extend across audiences with differing pre-existing views.

The co-PI successfully defended this dissertation at the University of California, Davis and archived it in ProQuest in 2024, under the supervision of the PI. In 2025, both studies from this project were accepted for presentation at the annual conference of the International Communication Association (ICA) in Denver, Colorado—one of the flagship conferences in the field of Communication. Notably, the manuscript based on Study 2 received a Top Paper Award from the Information Systems Division, reflecting the highest peer-review ratings and underscoring the academic significance of this work. Both studies are currently under review for publication in peer-reviewed academic journals.
